content: The Act titled "Governors Island Preservation and Development Act of 1998" establishes the Governors Island Commission under the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949. The Governors Island Commission is established under the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949. It consists of 11 members, including representatives from the General Services Administration, the Department of the Interior, and the Coast Guard, as well as individuals appointed by the President. The Governor of New York, the mayor of New York City, the speaker of the city council of New York City, a representative of a national historic preservation organization, and others will appoint members to the Governors Island Commission within 30 days of the enactment of this section. The Governors Island Commission will be appointed by various officials and a national historic preservation organization within 30 days of the enactment of this section. If recommendations are not made on time, the President can appoint members without regard to any late recommendations. Qualifications will be considered in the appointment process. The Governors Island Commission will be appointed by officials and a preservation organization within 30 days of enactment. The President can appoint members if recommendations are delayed. Qualifications for members include expertise in various fields. The Administrator of General Services will serve as the Commission's chairperson. Members will serve without compensation but will receive authorized travel expenses. The Governors Island Commission, appointed by officials and a preservation organization, will receive administrative support services and facilities from various agencies. The Commission's duties include conducting meetings, holding hearings, considering plans for Governors Island, and submitting recommendations within 180 days of all members being appointed. The Governors Island Commission will conduct meetings and hearings in New York City to gather public views on the island's disposition. They will submit a recommendation to the President within 180 days of all members being appointed. The Governors Island Commission in New York will recommend the disposition of the island, including ownership retention by the US or sale to public/private entities, rehabilitation of historic structures, use for various activities, and funding sources. The Governors Island Commission will recommend the disposition of the island, including ownership retention or sale, rehabilitation of structures, various activities, and funding sources. The recommendation may require assistance for economic feasibility, waiver of certain laws, and necessary legislation for implementation. The President has authority to implement the recommendation within 30 days with modifications if needed. The Governors Island Commission will make recommendations for the island's future, including ownership, rehabilitation, activities, and funding. The President can implement the recommendation within 30 days with modifications as needed, and the Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the recommendation. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended by striking section 9101 (111 Stat. 670) and transferring significant historic structures to the National Park Service. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to transfer administrative jurisdiction over historic structures on Governors Island, New York to the Secretary of the Interior for inclusion in the National Park System. Authorization of appropriations for maintenance and preservation of Governors Island and its structures by the Coast Guard and National Park Service: $12,000,000 for fiscal year 1999 and necessary sums for fiscal year 2000 onwards.
